title: Neville blasts Manchester United's squad following disastrous defeat to Newcastle
text:
Manchester United suffered a 1-0 defeat to Newcastle United at St James’ Park (Picture: Getty)

Gary Neville has criticised the quality and depth of Manchester United’s squad following their 1-0 defeat to Newcastle United at St James’ Park on Sunday.

United slumped to their third Premier League defeat of the season as 19-year-old Matty Longstaff fired in the winner after 72 minutes on his Premier League debut.

The result means that United are 15 points behind league leaders Liverpool and only two points clear of the relegation zone heading into the international break.

Matty Longstaff scored the winning goal on his Premier League debut for Newcastle United (Picture: Getty)

Although the club signed Harry Maguire, Aaron Wan-Bissaka and Daniel James in the summer, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s squad is light in key positions and Neville slammed the club’s recent recruitment as ‘woeful’.

‘The quality is not right, the depth of the squad is not good enough and they have taken a step back,’ Neville said on Sky Sports.

‘Losing Fellaini… they’d be better off with Fellaini up front with Lukaku and Sanchez upfront, there’s no doubt.

‘They ended the game there with six young players on the pitch so they would be better with those players on the pitch – Herrera – but they made the decision that those players aren’t going to get the club to where they want it to be in the long-term.

‘Some of them didn’t want to be at the club, some of them had the chance, some of them didn’t fit the style and they’re gone, there’s probably three or four more who need to go as well but the club needs to get the players in the transfer market.

‘Their recruitment has been bad and woeful for years and they’ve been all over the place in terms of different styles of managers, different players – they need to fix a style, fix a way of recruiting and go and get the players.’

It has been a miserable start to the season for United as they have collected just nine points from their opening eight Premier League matches representing their lowest return in the top-flight since the 1989-90 campaign.
